bug.short_desc: Bogus error caused by resolving a variable twice

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 246938 Example project that shows problem
In projects with annotation processors, it is possible to get bogus error messages.
Please try out the example project I have attached and see that there is an error message in Anno.java saying that A.X cannot be resolved to a variable. A.X is defined and you can even navigate to it using F3.
Here's what I believe is happening: 1. In the annotation processor there is a call to Elements#getElementValuesWithDefaults() 2. This causes type resolution for A.X since A.X is the default value for the foo() attribute for Anno.java using the method org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.ast.QualifiedNameReference.resolveType(BlockScope) 3. The type resolution of A.X causes the 'RestrictiveFlags' part of the 'bits' field of the binding for A.X to change from Binding.VARIABLE to Binding.FIELD 4. After the annotation processing the normal build begins. 5. A.X is again resolved but since the 'RestrictiveFlags' part of the 'bits' field for the A.X binding is Binding.FIELD, it does not match any of the cases in org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.ast.QualifiedNameReference.resolveType(BlockScope) and so an error is reported.
I don't really understand how the JDT compiler works so I haven't been able to find a fix for this issue.

Hi Harry, I get the following error message:
Internal compiler error: java.lang.UnsupportedClassVersionError: JVMCFRE003 bad major version; class=brokenanno/Processor, offset=6 at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClassImpl(Native Method)
Could you please let me know the JRE version you are using.
Is it 1.7 ?
Thanks
Hi Shankha, Yes, it was built with 1.7. You should be able to build the annotation processor JAR on your own with the jardesc provided in the project.
The issue is reproducible.
Can you look at the type node's resolvedType field and if it is non null binding avoid re-resolving from inside the annotation processor frame work ?

Created attachment 247894 Patch
(In reply to Srikanth Sankaran from comment #4) > Can you look at the type node's resolvedType field and if it is non null > binding avoid re-resolving from inside the annotation processor frame work ? I have a patch under test.
Shankha per comment#3 the issue is reproducible, please include a test. That way I can step through the code and see if the fix is good.

(In reply to Srikanth Sankaran from comment #6) > Shankha per comment#3 the issue is reproducible, please include a test. > That way I can step through the code and see if the fix is good.
Shankha, if you add a test I can verify the fix - thanks.

Hi Harry, Could you please share with the code of your annotation processor.
Thanks, Shankha

(In reply to shankha banerjee from comment #8) > Hi Harry, > Could you please share with the code of your annotation processor. > > Thanks, > Shankha
Hi Harry, Please ignore Comment 8. Sorry for the noise.
Thanks

The example given is not enough to show the bug. You also need an annotation processor that resolves the default value. I do this in my example with a call to Elements#getElementValuesWithDefaults(annotationMirror). A reproducible test case may be found in my attachment in Comment #1.

Is that enough to get the patch reviewed? I can provide a patch that converts my example project into something that can be run in a JUnit test for the annotation processor, though of course the test would fail until Shankha's patch is in.

(In reply to Harry Terkelsen from comment #12) > Is that enough to get the patch reviewed? I can provide a patch that > converts my example project into something that can be run in a JUnit test > for the annotation processor,
That could/should/would help.
> though of course the test would fail until > Shankha's patch is in
I basically need to see his fix in action to review/evaluate.

OK I'll write a patch that converts it into a test, but in the meantime if you want to see the patch in action on a reproducible case you can do the following:
1. Download https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=246938 2. Unzip the project inside into a workspace. 3. Right click "processor.jardesc" and do "Create JAR" 4. Project > Clean... 5. You should see the error marker "X cannot be resolved to a variable" on line 4 of Anno.java
If you try the same project with Shankha's patch applied, the error marker should not be present.

(In reply to Harry Terkelsen from comment #14) > OK I'll write a patch that converts it into a test, but in the meantime if > you want to see the patch in action on a reproducible case you can do the > following: > > 1. Download https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=246938 > 2. Unzip the project inside into a workspace. > 3. Right click "processor.jardesc" and do "Create JAR" > 4. Project > Clean... > 5. You should see the error marker "X cannot be resolved to a variable" on > line 4 of Anno.java > > If you try the same project with Shankha's patch applied, the error marker > should not be present.
I have the test case as part of org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.apt.tests. I will submit the patch by end of day today.
Thanks

(In reply to Harry Terkelsen from comment #14) > OK I'll write a patch that converts it into a test, but in the meantime if > you want to see the patch in action on a reproducible case you can do the > following: > > 1. Download https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=246938 > 2. Unzip the project inside into a workspace. > 3. Right click "processor.jardesc" and do "Create JAR" > 4. Project > Clean... > 5. You should see the error marker "X cannot be resolved to a variable" on > line 4 of Anno.java > > If you try the same project with Shankha's patch applied, the error marker > should not be present.
The project does compile cleanly with the fix.

(In reply to shankha banerjee from comment #15) > I have the test case as part of org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.apt.tests. > I will submit the patch by end of day today. >
I will try and finish it tomorrow. The suite org.eclipse.jdt.apt.pluggable.tests seems a better option than org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.apt.tests.
Thanks

Created attachment 248846 Patch
Test case added as part of the Patch.
1) All test results are good. 2) Test results are good for org.eclipse.jdt.apt.tests, org.eclipse.jdt.apt.pluggable.tests, org.eclipse.jdt.apt.tests.plugin and org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.apt.tests.
The way to test would be:
1) Apply the patch. 2) Please run org.eclipse.jdt.compiler.apt.tests\apttestprocessors.jardesc 3) Please run the test suite: AnnotationProcessorTests.
The test should succeed with the check in AnnotationMethodDeclaration and fail without the check.
Please review.
Thanks

Created attachment 248847 Patch
Updated Copyright information. Please look at Comment 18 regarding comments related to the patch.
Thanks
Thanks a lot to Jay for helping out with the test case.
Patch looks good to me.
Fixed through http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=47cd3e6cb31127575a1bbeda862fe74fff5aff5f
Fixed through http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=47cd3e6cb31127575a1bbeda862fe74fff5aff5f
Verified for 4.5 M4 with build I20141208-2000
